content: The Act is titled the "Postal Inspection Service and Inspector General Act" and restricts the Postal Service from using paid confidential informants. The Postal Service is prohibited from using paid confidential informants for investigations related to controlled substances unless the unlawful use of the mails is involved. They must report to Congress semiannually on investigations involving paid informants resulting in arrests for controlled substance violations. The Controlled Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970 prohibits the Postal Service from using paid confidential informants for controlled substance investigations unless mail misuse is involved. Paid informants must report investigations leading to controlled substance arrests to Congress. The amendment applies to investigations starting after the Act's enactment date.
